content: <?xml version='1.0' encoding='ISO-8859-1'?> <metadata> <idinfo> <smtype>1</smtype> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry - ATSDR</origin> <pubdate>20100526</pubdate> <pubtime /> <title>ATSDR Hazardous Waste Site Polygon Data, Version 2</title> <edition>2.00</edition> <geoform>vector</geoform> <serinfo> <sername /> <issue /> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Atlanta, GA</pubplace> <publish>Geospatial Research, Analysis, and Services Program (GRASP)</publish> </pubinfo> <othercit /> <onlink>http://dx.doi.org/10.7927/H48P5XF7</onlink> <smcilnkh>true</smcilnkh> <lworkcit> <citeinfo> <origin /> <pubdate /> <pubtime /> <title /> <edition /> <geoform /> <serinfo> <sername /> <issue /> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace /> <publish /> </pubinfo> <othercit /> <onlink /> <lworkcit /> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry (ATSDR) Hazardous Waste Site Polygon Data, Version 2 consists of 2,080 polygons for selected hazardous waste sites that were compiled on May 26, 2010. Most polygons represent sites considered for cleanup under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA or Superfund). Typical sites are either on the EPA National Priorities List (NPL) or are being considered for inclusion on the NPL. The hazardous waste site boundaries maintained by the Geospatial Research, Analysis, and Services Program (GRASP, Division of Health Studies, Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) contain NPL and non-NPL hazardous waste site boundaries for which health assessments or consultations have been requested.</abstract> <purpose>To provide the ATSDR polygon data set of hazardous waste sites in the United States, Puerto Rico, and other territories which can be used to identify nearby populations and assess their potential risk.</purpose> <supplinf /> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>20100526</caldate> <time /> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <current /> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>As needed</update> <citeinfo> <origin /> <pubdate /> <pubtime /> <title /> <edition /> <geoform /> <serinfo> <sername /> <issue /> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace /> <publish /> </pubinfo> <othercit /> <onlink /> <lworkcit /> </citeinfo> </toolcite> </tool> <webpub>false</webpub> </idinfo> <dataqual> <attracc> <attraccr /> <qattracc> <attraccv /> <attracce /> </qattracc> </attracc> <logic>Each site boundary is stored in an individual shapefile and the components of the shapefile (.shp, .dbf, .shx) are stored in a Microsoft Visual SourceSafe, a secure file control system. A history of each edit made to a shapefile (with corresponding comments) is maintained.  On a daily basis, these shapefiles are used to generate a Hazardous Waste Site polygon layer within the GRASP Geobase.  Any problems that are encountered during the creation of the Hazardous Waste Site layer are logged to a report that is accessible via the GRASP Intranet Web Site.</logic> <complete>A variety of data are used to define each site boundary that GRASP analyzes. These varying pieces of data include digital spatial data, USGS quad sheets, aerial photographs, topographic maps, GPS coordinates, and verbal descriptions. Although all pieces of information do not exist for each site, GRASP staff synthesizes information from as many sources as possible to develop an accurate site boundary.</complete> <posacc> <horizpa> Do not use</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>refresh_da</attrlabl> <attrdef>Refresh date of layer.  The layer is refreshed on a daily basis with site boundary files from a repository.  Thus, the layer contains the latest information that the GRASP team has compiled.</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>region</attrlabl> <attrdef>EPA region</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>site_id</attrlabl> <attrdef>SITE_ID should contain the EPA facility ID (e.g. GAD123456789), ATSDR Cost Recovery Number (e.g. GAXCR123456) or unique GRASP ID (e.g. GASAIDS897).  The GRASP ID is composed of the two-character state abbreviation + "SAIDS" + project number derived from the project management database. CERCLIS ID (ex: GAD123456789), ATSDR Cost Recovery ID (ex: GAXCR123456) or SAIDS Site ID (ex: GASAIDS987).  Keep in mind that CERCLIS ID\ufffds are ID\ufffds specified by CERCLIS (see epa.gov).  ATSDR Cost Recovery ID\ufffds are internal ID\ufffds created by ATSDR for sites that have no CERCLIS ID. SAIDS Site ID\ufffds are ID\ufffds created for sites that have neither CERCLIS ID\ufffds or ATSDR Cost Recovery ID\ufffds.</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>site_name</attrlabl> <attrdef>Site name of site</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>state</attrlabl> <attrdef>State</attrdef> <attrdefs>ATSDR</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv /> <edomvd /> <edomvds /> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea /> <enddatea /> <attrvai> <attrva /> <attrvae /> </attrvai> <attrmfrq /> <smcaptur>false</smcaptur> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>update_dat</attrlabl> <attrdef>NA.
